info: From garage-based book seller in Seattle to a behemoth of online retailing and entertainment

years.text: Amazon, founded in a Seattle garage by Jeff Bezos, starts simply by selling a huge array of books online. Originally Bezos wants to call the company Relentless and buys relentless.com – even today, that domain still redirects users to Amazon
Just two years into its history, Amazon lists on the NASDAQ at $18 per share
The company starts selling CDs and DVDs, with toys and electronics following on in 1999. Amazon expands into the UK the same year
Six years in, Amazon makes a quarterly profit of $5 million on revenues of more than $1 billion
Amazon makes an annual profit for the first time ($35.3 million). The previous year had seen a loss of nearly $150 million
Amazon Prime is introduced in the US, giving consumers faster deliveries for an annual charge. The UK gets Prime two years later
Amazon launches the Kindle
Amazon Studios is born, with the aim of providing original video content for the company’s streaming offering
Amazon moves into the tablet market with the Kindle Fire; meanwhile, its Netflix-style online video streaming service is launched at $79 a year
Amazon’s stock reaches $222 a share, while its market capitalisation smashes $100 billion
The Amazon Fire smartphone is launched. Amazon also purchases the .buy top level domain name for $4.6 million. Amazon now offers more than 2.5 million eBook titles for the Kindle
Amazon turns 20: it has a market capitalisation of nearly £250 billion
Amazon owns over 40 subsidiaries, and has nearly 270,000 employees around the world

info: They started off selling motorbike sidecars. Now they shift over half a million cars every year

years.text: Jaguar begins in 1922 as the Swallow Sidecar Company, a business making motorbike sidecars, thanks to a £1000 loan from a local bank
Expansion is so rapid that the company and its 50 employees relocate from Blackpool to Coventry, closer to the heart of the British motor industry
The workforce in Coventry stands at 15,00
The company’s name changes to Jaguar; the XK120 is launched three years later
Meanwhile, in Anglesey, Rover’s chief designer Maurice Wilks begins work on a Jeep prototype. The first Land Rover is officially launched the following year
Over 20 constabularies in Britain have Jaguar police cars
Jaguar starts building the legendary E-Type
The Range Rover is launched
The one millionth Land Rover is made
Ford offers to buy Jaguar
The Jaguar XJ220 becomes the world’s fastest car
After a period of difficulty for Jaguar, sales increase to 40,000 units and $2 billion. Meanwhile, the Rover Group – including Land Rover – is bought by BMW
BMW sells Land Rover to Ford for $3 billion. Ford aligns the brand closely with Jaguar
Ford sells Jaguar Land Rover to Tata after nearly 10 months of negotiations; the deal is financed with a $3 billion loan
An 11 per cent rise in profits sees Jaguar Land Rover head towards a £1 billion annual profit
The Range Rover Evoque is launched
Jaguar Land Rover’s revenues are £22 billion and they sell over 500,000 cars in a year for the first time

info: Its founder formed it at the age of just 17 with pocket money. These days, revenues are over €4 billion

years.text: At the age of just seven, future Ikea founder Ingvar Kamprad starts bulk-buying cheap matches and re-selling them individually at a good profit. He soon expands to greeting cards, pencils and biros
At just 17, using money he got from his father for doing well at school, Kamprad forms Ikea. Initially its range includes pens, wallets, picture frames and even nylon stockings

Kamprad takes out his first newspaper ad as demand begins to grow, using a local milk van to deliver products. Within three years, local manufacturers have helped Kamprad introduce furniture into the range
The first Ikea catalogue is published

While delivering a three-legged table to a customer, an Ikea worker struggles to get the table in the boot of his car, and removes the legs to make it fit and avoid damaging it. Inadvertently, flat-pack furniture is born
The first Ikea store opens in Almhult, Sweden
The first Ikea outside of Sweden opens in Oslo, Norway
The first Ikea outside of Scandinavia opens in Switzerland. Two later, they expand to Sydney, Australia
The iconic Billy bookcase is born
Ikea arrives in the USA. By this time it has 10,000 employees and 60 stores
Kamprad retires from CEO duties
Customers in Sweden can now buy the BoKlok – a flat-pack house
ikea.com is launched
By the end of the millennium, Ikea has 50,000 employees working in 158 stores in 29 countries
Customers in Sweden and Denmark are now able to buy via the website
Ikea now has over 100,000 employees in 44 countries

The famous Ikea catalogue now has 55 editions in 27 languages; the print run of around 200 million makes it twice as widely distributed as the Bible. The company is now so big that it is estimated that 10 per cent of all Europeans were conceived on an Ikea bed. The same year, pre-tax profits total £3.76 billion.
Net profit increases to €4.2 billion, with revenue standing at an astonishing €35.1 billion

info: What began as a root beer stand in the 1920s is now one of the world’s leading hotel chains

years.text: The Marriott company starts not as a hotel, but a root beer stand in Washington DC opened by JW Marriott and his wife Alice. It opens thanks to $6000 in savings that helped to pay for equipment and rent
The first Marriott hotel – the Twin Bridges Motor Hotel – opens in Virginia
The first Marriott to be built outside of the US is opened in Mexico
Cairo is home to the first Marriott hotel in Africa
The Twin Bridges Motor Hotel is demolished
Marriott buys 49 per cent of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company. That same year, it becomes the first company to offer its customers online reservation facilities
JW Marriott Jnr, son of JW Marriott, steps down as CEO after more than 40 years
Annual revenue exceeds $14 billion
The Marriott group has over 5,700 hotels in over 110 countries, with around 365,000 employees. Some way to celebrate a company’s 90th anniversary

info: Started by two computer geeks, it’s the company that made Bill Gates a billionaire at 31

years.text: Microsoft is started by two young Americans, Paul Allen and Bill Gates, after they write a bespoke programming language for the MITS Altair 8800 microcomputer. Gates is its first CEO
The company releases its first operating system, Xenix
Microsoft creates the MS-DOS operating system and only licences it to IBM, while retaining the rights
The fabled Microsoft Windows is released. Microsoft goes public and Gates is a billionaire at the age of 31
The company continues to evolve, with Microsoft Office the next program to be launched
Windows 95 is released, allowing people to connect to the internet via dial-up networking and the first version of Internet Explorer
Gates becomes chairman, handing over the CEO reins to Steve Ballmer, who’s been with Microsoft since 1980
Microsoft enters the gaming sector with the Xbox
The Xbox makes way for the Xbox 360, which is still available today
Gates is now an advisor to Microsoft, dedicating most of his time to his philanthropic Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Gates’s fortune is estimated at $78.5 billion, while he still owns 4.5 per cent of Microsoft
Microsoft reports a 27.8 per cent profit rise, with net income at $4.8 billion

info: Who’d have thought that this electronics giant began life as a £20 start-up exporting dried fish?

years.text: Samsung is founded in Taegu, Korea, by Byung-Chull Lee with 30,000 Won – the equivalent of £20 at today’s exchange rate. Rather than electronics, its initial offering is the export of dried fish, fruit and vegetables to China
Samsung already has its own flour mills and confectionery machinery. During the 1950s and 1960s, they diversify into other sectors such as textiles and life insurance
The company makes its first foray into the sector it will soon become famous in, as Samsung-Sanyo starts production of its first black and white television, the P-3202
The company’s rapid expansion sees the set-up of many new companies, such as Samsung Heavy Industries and Samsung Petrochemical. They also start making washing machines and fridges
Samsung produces its millionth black and white television. A year later they begin making colour TVs
Their four millionth black and white TV is made; a year later Samsung moves into microwaves, followed by air conditioning units in 1980
Samsung begins making personal computers, and starts exporting their newly-made VCR machines to America the following year
Samsung’s first mobile phone, the SH-100, is launched in Korea. It sells fewer than 2000 units
The company has now produced 20 million colour TVs. Meanwhile, it starts Samsung BP Chemicals with BP, selling chemical products in Korea
Samsung develops the world’s first 64M DRAM memory chip
Brings out a wireless internet smartphone, as well a full range of digital TVs
Samsung’s first Android phone, the Galaxy S, is introduced to the world. The following year, it is the world’s largest smartphone maker
Samsung teams up with Biogen and invests $255 million in Korean biopharmaceutical manufacturing
Samsung has over 7500 patents in America, more than any other company
The company announces an operating profit for the year of £29.2 trillion Won – around £20 billion. Not bad for a company started with £20

info: A loan of under $10,000 in 1971 launched a company that now has nearly 23,000 stores worldwide

years.text: Starbucks is founded by three friends from San Francisco University – Jerry Baldwin, Zav Siegl and Gordon Bowker – with each borrowing $1350. A further $5000 is borrowed, and the first outlet opens in Seattle. It only sells whole roasted beans, not brewed coffee
The company is bought by former employee Howard Schultz; there are currently six locations
Starbucks goes public. In five years it’s gone from six outlets to over 150 and revenues of $73.5 million, up from $1.3 million in 1987
Japanese branch becomes first Starbucks outside of North America. Total stores now stand at 1015
Expansion continues with the total number of global stores standing at 3,500
Buys Seattle Coffee Company. There are now 7,225 Starbucks stores around the world
Incredible expansion continues: there are now 16,858 Starbucks on earth
Starbucks buys the La Boulange bakery chain for $100 million
Revenues are now $14.89 billion
Starbucks iPhone app now has ‘shake to pay’ and digital tipping features
Number of stores totals 22,519, with outlets in over 60 countries

info: It started as a market stall 98 years ago. A century later, it’s Britain’s biggest supermarket

years.text: Jack Cohen starts selling groceries from an East End market stall; he uses demob money to buy the first day’s stock. Makes a profit of £1 on sales of £4
Tesco Tea becomes the company’s first own-brand product
The first ever Tesco store opens in Edgware, North London
Tesco floats on the Stock Exchange for 25p a share
Over 500 new stores are purchased during the next five years
The first Tesco supermarket opens in Maldon, Essex, with a cheese and meat counter
Household goods and clothing added to the range
Tesco opens its first petrol stations
Sales reach £1 billion
Sales reach £2 billion
Healthy Eating range launched
Tesco Value range and ‘Every Little Helps’ tagline launched
Tesco goes international by opening 26 stores in Hungary; meanwhile, it overtakes Sainsbury’s in UK market share
24-hour trading introduced
Tesco expands into Thailand, and South Korea the following year
Tesco.com launches
Tesco now in China
Buys garden centre chain, Dobbies, as it’s revealed that, as well as record profits of £2.5 billion, £1 in every £7 in the UK is spent in Tesco
World’s first zero-carbon supermarket in Ramsey, Cambridgeshire
Trading profit of Tesco is £1.4 billion

info: A hundred years ago they were selling soap and margarine. Turnover is now more than €50 billion

years.text: Having spent several years expanding their hand soap-making operation – now producing 135,000 tons of soap a year – William and James Lever buy Pears Soap. They also branch out into the margarine market
The Lever Brothers buy Wall’s sausages, which is also expanding into ice cream at the same time
The Lever Brothers and European company Margarine Unie agree to create Unilever
Despite the Second World War affecting Unilever’s European operations, it acquires Frozen Foods – owners of Bird’s Eye – as well as soup-makers Batchelor’s
Unilever launches Sunsilk shampoo
Unilever makes the first ever commercial TV advert for Gibbs SR toothpaste. The same year, it introduces Britain to the fish finger
The company launches the first ever margarine available in a tub. Meanwhile, Sunsilk shampoo is now available in 18 countries
Continuing with their talent for creating effective TV advertising campaigns, Unilever introduce Captain Bird’s Eye to the nation’s screens. The character remained on British screens until 2014
Unilever employs around 177,000 people in over 200 offices, investing £30 million annually on expansion
Unilever launches Vienetta ice cream. British dinner parties will never be the same again
Unilever takes the decision to remove trans-fats from all its foods
In a bid to reduce its portfolio, Unilever sheds 700 brands and now owns 900
Unilever’s World Food Programme delivers 17 million school meals to 80,000 children – just part of its mission of corporate responsibility
Turnover exceeds €50 billion
Unilever achieves its aim of saving a million tonnes of CO2 emissions since 2008

info: They’ve got over 2.3 million employees in 27 countries. Not bad for a company formed just 55 years ago

years.text: Aged 44, Sam Walton opens the first Walmart in Arkansas, US
Within five years Walmart owns 24 stores, with $12.7 million in sales
Walmart goes public at $16.50 per share.
The company goes onto the New York stock exchange. There are 51 stores to date, with recorded sales of $78 million
Walmart has 371,000 employees and 1,928 stores
Walmart records its first $1 billion sales week
It smashes $100 billion sales in a year for the first time
Walmart now employs more than 1.1 million in 3,989 stores worldwide
It tops the Fortune 500 ranking of US top companies for first time
Walmart has 2.3 million employees, with over 200 million customers a week in over 11,000 stores in 27 countries

info: Formed by Alan Sugar when he was just 20. Forty years later, he sold it and made £35 million

years.text: Aged 17, Alan Sugar begins selling reconditioned TVs from his house in Hackney
Amstrad, a company buying and selling electrical goods, is founded by Alan Sugar. The name is a play on Alan Michael Sugar Trading

Amstrad’s first venture is injection-moulded plastic turntable covers for hi-fis, which at £2.95 are considerably cheaper than their competitors’. A year later, the company records sales of £207,000, with a profit of £24,000
Profits now stand at £194,000
Amstrad lists on the London Stock Exchange. That year, turnover is £8.8 million and profit stands at £1.4 million

The first mass-market home computer package is launched, allowing Amstrad to take market share from Sinclair and Commodore. Meanwhile, at 37, Sugar wins The Guardian’s Young Businessman of the Year award

On a roll, Amstrad unveils the first mass-market word processor, the PCW 8,256. The following year, they bring out the first mass-market IBM-compatible PC, which at £399 costs a quarter of those from other market leaders
Amstrad now has a quarter of the PC market in Europe, and buys Sinclair computing for £5 million
It’s a big year for Amstrad: they launch the first mass-market satellite dish for Sky TV as well as the first combined phone, fax and answering machine
Amstrad enters the games console market with the GX4000. Its 8-bit technology can’t compete with the Sega Mega Drive and Super Nintendo’s 16-bit offering, and it flops
Amstrad acquires a 29.9% stake in telecommunications company Betacom – the first of several similar moves that steers the company away from computing
Amstrad launches the e-m@iler, a phone with an LCD screen and keyboard that allowed people to send emails and surf the web
Amstrad records sales of £102 million and a profit of £19 million
BskyB buys Amstrad for £125 million – a deal that makes sense given that Amstrad makes a third of the firm’s set-top boxes. Sir Alan Sugar makes £34.5 million from the deal

info: Steve Smith started it with a loan from his dad in 1990. Ten years later, he sold it for £50 million

years.text: Steve Smith opens the first Poundland in Burton-upon-Trent, partly thanks to a £50,000 loan from his dad. The store takes £13,000 on its first day
After a year, turnover stands at around £1 million with profits of £6000
With annual profits of over £4 million and 5500 employees, Smith sells Poundland for £50 million. He immediately gives his dad half as a thank you for the £50,000 loan back in 1991
The 100th Poundland store opens
The 200th Poundland store open
Poundland sells 185 million batteries, 21 million metres of tin foil, four million jars of coffee and half a million garden gnomes
The new store in Haringey becomes the 400th Poundland
Turnover is nearly £1 billion
Poundland is sold for £610 million
